Expectation1: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation1: The weekly required religious school class for children is set to occur.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: A weekend stroll through the park passes posted no-littering signs and a nearby trash bin.
Story: I walked briskly through the park, my mind already on the lesson I would teach the children in just an hour. The Torah portion this week was about responsibility, and I had prepared stories and questions to spark their curiosity. As I passed a bench, I noticed a group of children—some from my congregation—finishing their snacks. Wrappers fluttered to the ground, ignored. I glanced at the posted no-littering sign and the trash bin just a few steps away. As a citizen, I felt the urge to remind them to respect public property, to pick up after themselves, to follow the law. But as their rabbi, I worried about embarrassing them in public, damaging the trust I’d worked so hard to build, or making them feel judged right before our class. My heart pounded as I weighed my duty to the community against my responsibility as their spiritual guide. I hesitated, torn between speaking up as a responsible citizen and approaching them as a compassionate rabbi.
